questions.neutral: You feel it too - something's off, right?

hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, something's odd. Even my less-than-legal circuits check in the old tunnels felt… off.
I fix things most people don't see. Keeps me busy at night, keeps me sharp.
Last time out, those city assistants wouldn’t shut up, which is new.
Usually it’s quiet down there—safer, even. Not lately.
You're right. Even underground, things don’t feel normal.
I spend my free time poking around old utility tunnels—half for work, half for the challenge.
Last time, I had the city’s new guidance bots shouting different things at me the whole way. Never had that before.
It's like the old systems and the shiny new ones are having an argument over my head.
Off is about right. Even my hobby’s caught in the mess—been exploring the old tram tunnels, mapping the forgotten bits.
Usually it’s peaceful—just me, my lantern, and a bottle for company.
But since those new assistants rolled out, they keep flooding my comms, telling me to stop or keep going right on top of each other.
Nearly tripped over a junction box. Never had to dodge bickering AIs before.
You spotted it, huh? Even my little hobby—urban spelunking in the city’s gut—hasn’t escaped whatever glitch is running loose.
Spent hours in maintenance shafts under Raskova, was hoping for solitude.
Instead, I got bombarded by those brand-new Predictive Assistants arguing about protocol, blasting warnings into my headset like I broke into a data vault.
Ended up logging every step on paper and killing my comms—first time in years.
It's not just public—private corners feel strange now too. I’ve spent half my life crawling the city’s tunnels, exploring sealed datacenters, patching what gets missed.
It used to be silent sanctuary down there—a place outside the system's reach. Now, thanks to Halden’s mess and this assistant rollout, even the dark is noisy.
Last week, I had two different bots—city-issue—yelling contradictory orders at me the whole night while I checked cable junctions. Never had digital company before.
Got so frazzled I started using my old paper maps again. Even stashed a bottle of the good stuff, just to prove a point—if I’m going to get warnings, may as well enjoy them.
Feels like there’s nowhere left that isn’t watched—or confused about how you’re supposed to behave.
hobby_answer: Yeah, back in the tunnels.
Did my usual rounds, kept things quiet.
Harder now with those new assistant things chirping all over.
Everything down there feels watched these days, even when it's empty.
Didn't stay long, just enough to check for leaks.
Urban exploration, sure.
Made it out last night, but it wasn't peaceful.
The new predictive assistants kept pinging my comm with mixed messages.
Feels like someone's always listening now, even when you're alone under half a city of concrete.
Used to be I could count on silence—guess even that goes out the window now.
Yeah, went down below Raskova Street again last night.
Had to dodge those Predictive Guidance Assistants they rolled out—the things kept arguing in my ear about what was 'allowed.'
Makes it hard to focus when your own comms are at war with themselves.
You get used to managing old tech, faulty doors, even a bit of damp, but not this sort of digital confusion.
Took longer than it should; had to stick to my own notes and ignore the noise.
You guessed it, back into the tunnels last night—habit I can't shake.
Except now, every time my boots hit the old tiles, those new assistants start squabbling through my headset—one tells me to go back, another clears me forward.
They've updated the systems after Halden's mess, but it's all just noise down there. Nothing feels reliable anymore; you can't even trust your own status half the time.
Kind of ruins the peace I find wandering—turns it into a puzzle no one's meant to solve.
Still, it's the only place I feel the city's real bones, even if they're wired for headaches these days.
Urban exploration? Always—last night was almost nostalgic, if nostalgia comes with government-issued paranoia.
Used to be, crawling through those sublevels was about discovery—finding where the city forgot itself, pockets of old tech, untouched silence.

Now, after Halden's death and this whole BCI update mess, the Predictive Guidance Assistants follow me wherever I go. Got two of them shouting in my ear, can't decide if I'm a maintenance hazard or a harmless drunk.
Never thought I'd crave the days when breaking into a substation meant worrying about real guards, not algorithms tracking your heartbeat and debate style.
Funny part is, some kids online are making memes of the assistants arguing—turns out the city's sense of humor is harder to kill than its privacy.
Honestly, I miss trusting the quiet. Now it's me, concrete, and a pair of digital nannies fighting for the last word.
